bibl.title: Surgeon General's Office Record Card for Walter Reed, May 14, 1901

div1.p: The record card explains Walter Reed's leave of absence for 1901, with reference to an unexplained absence from his post as member of the Army Medical Examining Board. The report also states that Reed is personally and professionally humiliated by this inquiry. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Surgeon General's Office Record Card for Walter Reed, May 14, 1901
div1.p:
G.M.S. S.G., U.S.A.
F
B.M.I.
May 14, 1901. Major Walter Reed, Surg
U.S.A., Wash. D.C. (Through Col. Cal-
vin DeWitt, Presdt. Army Med. Ex, Board
Sir: An explanation is desired with
reference to your absence from your
duties as a member of the Army Med.
Examining Board convened in this
city by paragraph 1, S.O. 28, A.G.O.,
3-958
Write nothing below this line
Feb. 2, 1901.
G.M.S., S.G., U.S.A.
B.M.I.

F
May 16, 1901 Reed back
Maj. Reed states he had
supposed that he had
the authority of the Surg.
Genl., conveyed by tele-
phone through his Chief
clerk, for absence from
the city and from duty
as a member of the
Examining Board during
the past week. States he
certainly requested Mr.
Jones to say to the S.G.
that he had arranged
with two members of the
Board to assume his du-
ties during the coming
week. If, however, the
S.G. decides that he was
absent without authority,
in fairness to the service,
requests that the Pay
Dept. be officially in-
formed, so that his pay
may be deducted for
such number of days
absence without leave
adds: “as this is the first ←
time, during a service
of nearly 26 years, that
I have been called upon
for an explanation for
absence from or neglect
of duty, of any descrip-
tion whatever, this com-
munication becomes to
me the source of very
great personal and pro-
fessional humiliation.”
W.E.E.

May 16, 1901. Resp'y returned
to Maj. Walter Reed, Surg., U.S.A.
through Col. Calvin DeWitt, Asst.
Surg. General, U.S.A., President,
Army Medical Board. The message
given to me by Mr. Jones, Chief
Clerk, S.G.O., was to the effect
that Major Reed desired to be
absent until the Wednesday
following the date (May 3d)
[unclear] Write nothing below this line.
of his request by telephone -
i.e. until Wednesday May 8th,
and I approved of this absence.
As a matter of fact Major Reed
was absent from May 4th to
May 15th. As there appears to
have been a misapprehension
with reference to the duration
of the absence authorized I
shall give no further consider-
ation to the matter.
